Day 18 : Understanding the difference between == and .equals() in Java is crucial for comparing objects correctly. Day 18 : Understanding the difference between == and .equals() in Java is crucial for comparing objects correctly. Here's a fun and interactive way to grasp these concepts.ğŸ§  Understanding == vs .equals() in JavağŸ” The == OperatorWhat it does: Checks if two references point to the exact same object in memory.Use case: Best for comparing primitive data types (like int, char) or checking if two object references are identical.Medium+2Medium+2Scaler+2ğŸ§ª The .equals() MethodWhat it does: Compares the actual content or state of two objects.Use case: Ideal for comparing the contents of objects, such as strings, to see if they are logically "equal."ğŸ–¼ï¸ Visual RepresentationImagine two identical books:Scenario 1: Both friends are reading the same physical book. This is like using ==; both references point to the same object.Scenario 2: Each friend has their own copy of the book with the same  content. This is like using .equals(); different objects, but               identical content.ğŸ® Interactive Coding ChallengeLet's play a game with Java strings!javaCopyEditpublic class StringComparison { public static void main(String[] args) { String magicWord1 = "Abracadabra"; String magicWord2 = "Abracadabra"; String magicWord3 = new String("Abracadabra"); System.out.println(magicWord1 == magicWord2); // What will this print? System.out.println(magicWord1 == magicWord3); // And this? System.out.println(magicWord1.equals(magicWord3)); // How about this? }}ğŸ“Œ Follow along and challenge yourself daily!ğŸ’¡ I'll be sharing one Java trick daily! Here's a fun and interactive way to grasp these concepts.ğŸ§  Understanding == vs .equals() in JavağŸ” The == OperatorWhat it does: Checks if two references point to the exact same object in memory.Use case: Best for comparing primitive data types (like int, char) or checking if two object references are identical.Medium+2Medium+2Scaler+2ğŸ§ª The .equals() MethodWhat it does: Compares the actual content or state of two objects.Use case: Ideal for comparing the contents of objects, such as strings, to see if they are logically "equal."ğŸ–¼ï¸ Visual RepresentationImagine two identical books:Scenario 1: Both friends are reading the same physical book. This is like using ==; both references point to the same object.Scenario 2: Each friend has their own copy of the book with the same  content. This is like using .equals(); different objects, but               identical content.ğŸ® Interactive Coding ChallengeLet's play a game with Java strings!javaCopyEditpublic class StringComparison { public static void main(String[] args) { String magicWord1 = "Abracadabra"; String magicWord2 = "Abracadabra"; String magicWord3 = new String("Abracadabra"); System.out.println(magicWord1 == magicWord2); // What will this print? System.out.println(magicWord1 == magicWord3); // And this? System.out.println(magicWord1.equals(magicWord3)); // How about this? }}ğŸ“Œ Follow along and challenge yourself daily!ğŸ’¡ I'll be sharing one Java trick daily! Back in 2020/21, remote work was hailed as the future. We saw bold predictions. More flexibility, reduced office space, asynchronous work, even the idea of holding multiple jobs remotely.Now in 2025, reality looks different.  Some gains held: hybrid work is more common, digital collaboration tools have matured, and employees expect flexibility. But letâ€™s be honest, many organizations have quietly reverted. Office mandates are back. The 8â€“5 structure remains dominant, and leadership? In many cases, still measuring productivity by attendance, not outcomes.What does this tell us?  Change happened, but not transformation. We adapted under pressure, but didnâ€™t redesign systems for the long term.If we are serious about the future of work, we need to stop treating flexibility as a perk and start embedding it into culture, policy, and performance management.2020 showed us whatâ€™s possible. 2025 is showing us whoâ€™s actually committed.hashtag#FutureOfWork hashtag#Leadership hashtag#WorkplaceCulture hashtag#RemoteWork hashtag#HRStrategy

Day 18 : Understanding the difference between == and .equals() in Java is crucial for comparing objects correctly. Here's a fun and interactive way to grasp these concepts.ğŸ§  Understanding == vs .equals() in JavağŸ” The == OperatorWhat it does: Checks if two references point to the exact same object in memory.Use case: Best for comparing primitive data types (like int, char) or checking if two object references are identical.Medium+2Medium+2Scaler+2ğŸ§ª The .equals() MethodWhat it does: Compares the actual content or state of two objects.Use case: Ideal for comparing the contents of objects, such as strings, to see if they are logically "equal."ğŸ–¼ï¸ Visual RepresentationImagine two identical books:Scenario 1: Both friends are reading the same physical book. This is like using ==; both references point to the same object.Scenario 2: Each friend has their own copy of the book with the same  content. This is like using .equals(); different objects, but               identical content.ğŸ® Interactive Coding ChallengeLet's play a game with Java strings!javaCopyEditpublic class StringComparison { public static void main(String[] args) { String magicWord1 = "Abracadabra"; String magicWord2 = "Abracadabra"; String magicWord3 = new String("Abracadabra"); System.out.println(magicWord1 == magicWord2); // What will this print? System.out.println(magicWord1 == magicWord3); // And this? System.out.println(magicWord1.equals(magicWord3)); // How about this? }}ğŸ“Œ Follow along and challenge yourself daily!ğŸ’¡ I'll be sharing one Java trick daily! Back in 2020/21, remote work was hailed as the future. We saw bold predictions. More flexibility, reduced office space, asynchronous work, even the idea of holding multiple jobs remotely.Now in 2025, reality looks different.  Some gains held: hybrid work is more common, digital collaboration tools have matured, and employees expect flexibility. But letâ€™s be honest, many organizations have quietly reverted. Office mandates are back. The 8â€“5 structure remains dominant, and leadership? In many cases, still measuring productivity by attendance, not outcomes.What does this tell us?  Change happened, but not transformation. Day 18 : Understanding the difference between == and .equals() in Java is crucial for comparing objects correctly. Here's a fun and interactive way to grasp these concepts.ğŸ§  Understanding == vs .equals() in JavağŸ” The == OperatorWhat it does: Checks if two references point to the exact same object in memory.Use case: Best for comparing primitive data types (like int, char) or checking if two object references are identical.Medium+2Medium+2Scaler+2ğŸ§ª The .equals() MethodWhat it does: Compares the actual content or state of two objects.Use case: Ideal for comparing the contents of objects, such as strings, to see if they are logically "equal."ğŸ–¼ï¸ Visual RepresentationImagine two identical books:Scenario 1: Both friends are reading the same physical book. This is like using ==; both references point to the same object.Scenario 2: Each friend has their own copy of the book with the same  content. This is like using .equals(); different objects, but               identical content.ğŸ® Interactive Coding ChallengeLet's play a game with Java strings!javaCopyEditpublic class StringComparison { public static void main(String[] args) { String magicWord1 = "Abracadabra"; String magicWord2 = "Abracadabra"; String magicWord3 = new String("Abracadabra"); System.out.println(magicWord1 == magicWord2); // What will this print? System.out.println(magicWord1 == magicWord3); // And this? System.out.println(magicWord1.equals(magicWord3)); // How about this? }}ğŸ“Œ Follow along and challenge yourself daily!ğŸ’¡ I'll be sharing one Java trick daily! Back in 2020/21, remote work was hailed as the future. We saw bold predictions. More flexibility, reduced office space, asynchronous work, even the idea of holding multiple jobs remotely.Now in 2025, reality looks different.  Some gains held: hybrid work is more common, digital collaboration tools have matured, and employees expect flexibility. But letâ€™s be honest, many organizations have quietly reverted. Office mandates are back. The 8â€“5 structure remains dominant, and leadership? In many cases, still measuring productivity by attendance, not outcomes.What does this tell us?  Change happened, but not transformation. We adapted under pressure, but didnâ€™t redesign systems for the long term.If we are serious about the future of work, we need to stop treating flexibility as a perk and start embedding it into culture, policy, and performance management.2020 showed us whatâ€™s possible. 2025 is showing us whoâ€™s actually committed.hashtag#FutureOfWork hashtag#Leadership hashtag#WorkplaceCulture hashtag#RemoteWork hashtag#HRStrategy

When NVS Fails on ESP32â€¦ LittleFS to the Rescue! In one of our recent IoT projects, we ran into a tricky issue after rolling out a new firmware update (OTA) to all our ESP32-based devices. Out of nearly 30,000 units, about 100 started acting weirdâ€”some configs didnâ€™t load properly, and things just didnâ€™t add up.After digging into it, we found the root cause: we had increased the EEPROM size from 2KB to 5KB, and it turned out NVS couldnâ€™t handle it well on all devices.When we scanned the full memory, we saw corruption issues in those affected devices. ğŸ˜¬So, together with my teammates, we decided to shift our strategy.We moved our data and device configurations from NVS to SPIFFS using LittleFS ---> and it worked like a charm! ğŸ‹  Everything became stable and clean again.ğŸ” A quick takeaway:Sometimes NVS isn't the best fit for larger or dynamic data. LittleFS gave us the reliability we needed for this scale of deployment.Just wanted to share in case someone else is hitting a similar wallâ€”hope it saves you some time!hashtag#ESP32 hashtag#IoT hashtag#LittleFS hashtag#NVS hashtag#SPIFFS hashtag#FirmwareUpdate hashtag#EmbeddedSystems hashtag#MemoryManagement hashtag#TechFix

Day 18 : Understanding the difference between == and .equals() in Java is crucial for comparing objects correctly. Here's a fun and interactive way to grasp these concepts.ğŸ§  Understanding == vs .equals() in JavağŸ” The == OperatorWhat it does: Checks if two references point to the exact same object in memory.Use case: Best for comparing primitive data types (like int, char) or checking if two object references are identical.Medium+2Medium+2Scaler+2ğŸ§ª The .equals() MethodWhat it does: Compares the actual content or state of two objects.Use case: Ideal for comparing the contents of objects, such as strings, to see if they are logically "equal."ğŸ–¼ï¸ Visual RepresentationImagine two identical books:Scenario 1: Both friends are reading the same physical book. This is like using ==; both references point to the same object.Scenario 2: Each friend has their own copy of the book with the same  content. This is like using .equals(); different objects, but               identical content.ğŸ® Interactive Coding ChallengeLet's play a game with Java strings!javaCopyEditpublic class StringComparison { public static void main(String[] args) { String magicWord1 = "Abracadabra"; String magicWord2 = "Abracadabra"; String magicWord3 = new String("Abracadabra"); System.out.println(magicWord1 == magicWord2); // What will this print? System.out.println(magicWord1 == magicWord3); // And this? System.out.println(magicWord1.equals(magicWord3)); // How about this? }}ğŸ“Œ Follow along and challenge yourself daily!ğŸ’¡ I'll be sharing one Java trick daily! Back in 2020/21, remote work was hailed as the future. We saw bold predictions. More flexibility, reduced office space, asynchronous work, even the idea of holding multiple jobs remotely.Now in 2025, reality looks different.  Some gains held: hybrid work is more common, digital collaboration tools have matured, and employees expect flexibility. But letâ€™s be honest, many organizations have quietly reverted. Office mandates are back. The 8â€“5 structure remains dominant, and leadership? In many cases, still measuring productivity by attendance, not outcomes.What does this tell us?  Change happened, but not transformation. We adapted under pressure, but didnâ€™t redesign systems for the long term.If we are serious about the future of work, we need to stop treating flexibility as a perk and start embedding it into culture, policy, and performance management.2020 showed us whatâ€™s possible. 2025 is showing us whoâ€™s actually committed.hashtag#FutureOfWork hashtag#Leadership hashtag#WorkplaceCulture hashtag#RemoteWork hashtag#HRStrategy

When NVS Fails on ESP32â€¦ LittleFS to the Rescue! In one of our recent IoT projects, we ran into a tricky issue after rolling out a new firmware update (OTA) to all our ESP32-based devices. Out of nearly 30,000 units, about 100 started acting weirdâ€”some configs didnâ€™t load properly, and things just didnâ€™t add up.After digging into it, we found the root cause: we had increased the EEPROM size from 2KB to 5KB, and it turned out NVS couldnâ€™t handle it well on all devices.When we scanned the full memory, we saw corruption issues in those affected devices. ğŸ˜¬So, together with my teammates, we decided to shift our strategy.We moved our data and device configurations from NVS to SPIFFS using LittleFS ---> and it worked like a charm! ğŸ‹  Everything became stable and clean again.ğŸ” A quick takeaway:Sometimes NVS isn't the best fit for larger or dynamic data. LittleFS gave us the reliability we needed for this scale of deployment.Just wanted to share in case someone else is hitting a similar wallâ€”hope it saves you some time!hashtag#ESP32 hashtag#IoT hashtag#LittleFS hashtag#NVS hashtag#SPIFFS hashtag#FirmwareUpdate hashtag#EmbeddedSystems hashtag#MemoryManagement hashtag#TechFix

"ÙˆÙÙ‚ÙÙ„ Ø±ÙÙ‘Ø¨ÙÙ‘ Ø²ÙØ¯Ù’Ù†ÙÙŠ Ø¹ÙÙ„Ù’Ù…Ù‹Ø§" â€“ Ø³ÙˆØ±Ø© Ø·Ù‡ØŒ Ø§Ù„Ø¢ÙŠØ© 114ğŸ”§ MCSA Project 5: Deploying a Multi-Site Domain Controller with IFM and NIC Teaming â€“ A Real-World SimulationIâ€™ve just completed my fifth and most comprehensive MCSA project so far â€” a full-scale enterprise-level deployment involving multiple sites, advanced domain replication, and optimized server communication. Here's a breakdown of what I implemented:1ï¸âƒ£ Creating IFM Media for Domain Replication To simulate a real-world "Install From Media" (IFM) scenario, I generated a custom IFM package containing the Active Directory database and SYSVOL. Using ntdsutil via elevated CMD, I navigated to the IFM module and executed the command: create sysvol full C:\ifm This IFM folder allows a new domain controller to be promoted without replicating over the WAN â€” ideal for branch offices.2ï¸âƒ£ Lab Structure and Configuration I designed two sites: Cairo and Mansoura.Cairoâ€™s Server 2016 was configured as a Primary Domain Controller (PDC) and joined with a Windows 10 client in the same domain.The network was fully connected (pingable), and proper domain resolution was ensured through DNS configuration.I added a second Ethernet adapter and implemented NIC Teaming, enhancing bandwidth and redundancy.ğŸ’¡ NIC Teaming Benefits:Increased throughput via load balancingNetwork fault toleranceSeamless connectivity in case of NIC failure3ï¸âƒ£ Cloning and SID Regeneration for New Site To prepare the Mansoura site, I cloned the Cairo server and changed its SID using Sysprep to avoid domain conflicts. Upon reboot, the server was demoted to a Workgroup â€” a critical step in separating domain identity between sites.4ï¸âƒ£ Establishing Trust & Promoting the ADCI reconnected the Mansoura server to the Cairo network.Ensured two-way communication was functional (DNS + pingable).Installed Active Directory Domain Services on Mansoura's server.Promoted it as an Additional Domain Controller (ADC) using credentials from the existing domain (tshoot\administrator).Selected Mansoura as the site and enabled both DNS and Global Catalog roles.5ï¸âƒ£ IFM-Based User Replication Post-promotion, I imported the users from the previously created IFM folder. âœ… Users created in Cairo were instantly visible in Mansoura â€” proving successful replication.6ï¸âƒ£ Final TouchesRenamed servers accordingly: PDC (Cairo) and ADC (Mansoura)Disabled firewalls to avoid blocking replication or communicationInstalled VMware Tools to enhance performance and integrationğŸ’¼ This project was a deep dive into multi-site domain architecture, replication, network optimization, and disaster recovery readiness â€” and honestly, it felt like managing an enterprise-level infrastructure.Always striving to learn by doing, and this one was a milestone.Mohamed Tarek Zyad Waleed Elzyat Ali Khaled hashtag#MCSA hashtag#ActiveDirectory hashtag#Sysadmin hashtag#WindowsServer2016 hashtag#Networking hashtag#ITInfrastructure hashtag#NICTeaming hashtag#InstallFromMedia hashtag#LinkedInLearning hashtag#SysadminLife hashtag#MCSE hashtag#ITProjects

Day 18 : Understanding the difference between == and .equals() in Java is crucial for comparing objects correctly. Here's a fun and interactive way to grasp these concepts.ğŸ§  Understanding == vs .equals() in JavağŸ” The == OperatorWhat it does: Checks if two references point to the exact same object in memory.Use case: Best for comparing primitive data types (like int, char) or checking if two object references are identical.Medium+2Medium+2Scaler+2ğŸ§ª The .equals() MethodWhat it does: Compares the actual content or state of two objects.Use case: Ideal for comparing the contents of objects, such as strings, to see if they are logically "equal."ğŸ–¼ï¸ Visual RepresentationImagine two identical books:Scenario 1: Both friends are reading the same physical book. This is like using ==; both references point to the same object.Scenario 2: Each friend has their own copy of the book with the same  content. This is like using .equals(); different objects, but               identical content.ğŸ® Interactive Coding ChallengeLet's play a game with Java strings!javaCopyEditpublic class StringComparison { public static void main(String[] args) { String magicWord1 = "Abracadabra"; String magicWord2 = "Abracadabra"; String magicWord3 = new String("Abracadabra"); System.out.println(magicWord1 == magicWord2); // What will this print? System.out.println(magicWord1 == magicWord3); // And this? System.out.println(magicWord1.equals(magicWord3)); // How about this? }}ğŸ“Œ Follow along and challenge yourself daily!ğŸ’¡ I'll be sharing one Java trick daily! Back in 2020/21, remote work was hailed as the future. We saw bold predictions. More flexibility, reduced office space, asynchronous work, even the idea of holding multiple jobs remotely.Now in 2025, reality looks different.  Some gains held: hybrid work is more common, digital collaboration tools have matured, and employees expect flexibility. But letâ€™s be honest, many organizations have quietly reverted. Office mandates are back. The 8â€“5 structure remains dominant, and leadership? In many cases, still measuring productivity by attendance, not outcomes.What does this tell us?  Change happened, but not transformation. We adapted under pressure, but didnâ€™t redesign systems for the long term.If we are serious about the future of work, we need to stop treating flexibility as a perk and start embedding it into culture, policy, and performance management.2020 showed us whatâ€™s possible. 2025 is showing us whoâ€™s actually committed.hashtag#FutureOfWork hashtag#Leadership hashtag#WorkplaceCulture hashtag#RemoteWork hashtag#HRStrategy

When NVS Fails on ESP32â€¦ LittleFS to the Rescue! In one of our recent IoT projects, we ran into a tricky issue after rolling out a new firmware update (OTA) to all our ESP32-based devices. Out of nearly 30,000 units, about 100 started acting weirdâ€”some configs didnâ€™t load properly, and things just didnâ€™t add up.After digging into it, we found the root cause: we had increased the EEPROM size from 2KB to 5KB, and it turned out NVS couldnâ€™t handle it well on all devices.When we scanned the full memory, we saw corruption issues in those affected devices. ğŸ˜¬So, together with my teammates, we decided to shift our strategy.We moved our data and device configurations from NVS to SPIFFS using LittleFS ---> and it worked like a charm! ğŸ‹  Everything became stable and clean again.ğŸ” A quick takeaway:Sometimes NVS isn't the best fit for larger or dynamic data. LittleFS gave us the reliability we needed for this scale of deployment.Just wanted to share in case someone else is hitting a similar wallâ€”hope it saves you some time!hashtag#ESP32 hashtag#IoT hashtag#LittleFS hashtag#NVS hashtag#SPIFFS hashtag#FirmwareUpdate hashtag#EmbeddedSystems hashtag#MemoryManagement hashtag#TechFix

"ÙˆÙÙ‚ÙÙ„ Ø±ÙÙ‘Ø¨ÙÙ‘ Ø²ÙØ¯Ù’Ù†ÙÙŠ Ø¹ÙÙ„Ù’Ù…Ù‹Ø§" â€“ Ø³ÙˆØ±Ø© Ø·Ù‡ØŒ Ø§Ù„Ø¢ÙŠØ© 114ğŸ”§ MCSA Project 5: Deploying a Multi-Site Domain Controller with IFM and NIC Teaming â€“ A Real-World SimulationIâ€™ve just completed my fifth and most comprehensive MCSA project so far â€” a full-scale enterprise-level deployment involving multiple sites, advanced domain replication, and optimized server communication. Here's a breakdown of what I implemented:1ï¸âƒ£ Creating IFM Media for Domain Replication To simulate a real-world "Install From Media" (IFM) scenario, I generated a custom IFM package containing the Active Directory database and SYSVOL. Using ntdsutil via elevated CMD, I navigated to the IFM module and executed the command: create sysvol full C:\ifm This IFM folder allows a new domain controller to be promoted without replicating over the WAN â€” ideal for branch offices.2ï¸âƒ£ Lab Structure and Configuration I designed two sites: Cairo and Mansoura.Cairoâ€™s Server 2016 was configured as a Primary Domain Controller (PDC) and joined with a Windows 10 client in the same domain.The network was fully connected (pingable), and proper domain resolution was ensured through DNS configuration.I added a second Ethernet adapter and implemented NIC Teaming, enhancing bandwidth and redundancy.ğŸ’¡ NIC Teaming Benefits:Increased throughput via load balancingNetwork fault toleranceSeamless connectivity in case of NIC failure3ï¸âƒ£ Cloning and SID Regeneration for New Site To prepare the Mansoura site, I cloned the Cairo server and changed its SID using Sysprep to avoid domain conflicts. Upon reboot, the server was demoted to a Workgroup â€” a critical step in separating domain identity between sites.4ï¸âƒ£ Establishing Trust & Promoting the ADCI reconnected the Mansoura server to the Cairo network.Ensured two-way communication was functional (DNS + pingable).Installed Active Directory Domain Services on Mansoura's server.Promoted it as an Additional Domain Controller (ADC) using credentials from the existing domain (tshoot\administrator).Selected Mansoura as the site and enabled both DNS and Global Catalog roles.5ï¸âƒ£ IFM-Based User Replication Post-promotion, I imported the users from the previously created IFM folder. âœ… Users created in Cairo were instantly visible in Mansoura â€” proving successful replication.6ï¸âƒ£ Final TouchesRenamed servers accordingly: PDC (Cairo) and ADC (Mansoura)Disabled firewalls to avoid blocking replication or communicationInstalled VMware Tools to enhance performance and integrationğŸ’¼ This project was a deep dive into multi-site domain architecture, replication, network optimization, and disaster recovery readiness â€” and honestly, it felt like managing an enterprise-level infrastructure.Always striving to learn by doing, and this one was a milestone.Mohamed Tarek Zyad Waleed Elzyat Ali Khaled hashtag#MCSA hashtag#ActiveDirectory hashtag#Sysadmin hashtag#WindowsServer2016 hashtag#Networking hashtag#ITInfrastructure hashtag#NICTeaming hashtag#InstallFromMedia hashtag#LinkedInLearning hashtag#SysadminLife hashtag#MCSE hashtag#ITProjects

Day 18 : Understanding the difference between == and .equals() in Java is crucial for comparing objects correctly. Here's a fun and interactive way to grasp these concepts.ğŸ§  Understanding == vs .equals() in JavağŸ” The == OperatorWhat it does: Checks if two references point to the exact same object in memory.Use case: Best for comparing primitive data types (like int, char) or checking if two object references are identical.Medium+2Medium+2Scaler+2ğŸ§ª The .equals() MethodWhat it does: Compares the actual content or state of two objects.Use case: Ideal for comparing the contents of objects, such as strings, to see if they are logically "equal."ğŸ–¼ï¸ Visual RepresentationImagine two identical books:Scenario 1: Both friends are reading the same physical book. This is like using ==; both references point to the same object.Scenario 2: Each friend has their own copy of the book with the same  content. This is like using .equals(); different objects, but               identical content.ğŸ® Interactive Coding ChallengeLet's play a game with Java strings!javaCopyEditpublic class StringComparison { public static void main(String[] args) { String magicWord1 = "Abracadabra"; String magicWord2 = "Abracadabra"; String magicWord3 = new String("Abracadabra"); System.out.println(magicWord1 == magicWord2); // What will this print? System.out.println(magicWord1 == magicWord3); // And this? System.out.println(magicWord1.equals(magicWord3)); // How about this? }}ğŸ“Œ Follow along and challenge yourself daily!ğŸ’¡ I'll be sharing one Java trick daily! Back in 2020/21, remote work was hailed as the future. We saw bold predictions. More flexibility, reduced office space, asynchronous work, even the idea of holding multiple jobs remotely.Now in 2025, reality looks different.  Some gains held: hybrid work is more common, digital collaboration tools have matured, and employees expect flexibility. But letâ€™s be honest, many organizations have quietly reverted. Office mandates are back. The 8â€“5 structure remains dominant, and leadership? In many cases, still measuring productivity by attendance, not outcomes.What does this tell us?  Change happened, but not transformation. We adapted under pressure, but didnâ€™t redesign systems for the long term.If we are serious about the future of work, we need to stop treating flexibility as a perk and start embedding it into culture, policy, and performance management.2020 showed us whatâ€™s possible. 2025 is showing us whoâ€™s actually committed.hashtag#FutureOfWork hashtag#Leadership hashtag#WorkplaceCulture hashtag#RemoteWork hashtag#HRStrategy

When NVS Fails on ESP32â€¦ LittleFS to the Rescue! In one of our recent IoT projects, we ran into a tricky issue after rolling out a new firmware update (OTA) to all our ESP32-based devices. Out of nearly 30,000 units, about 100 started acting weirdâ€”some configs didnâ€™t load properly, and things just didnâ€™t add up.After digging into it, we found the root cause: we had increased the EEPROM size from 2KB to 5KB, and it turned out NVS couldnâ€™t handle it well on all devices.When we scanned the full memory, we saw corruption issues in those affected devices. ğŸ˜¬So, together with my teammates, we decided to shift our strategy.We moved our data and device configurations from NVS to SPIFFS using LittleFS ---> and it worked like a charm! ğŸ‹  Everything became stable and clean again.ğŸ” A quick takeaway:Sometimes NVS isn't the best fit for larger or dynamic data. LittleFS gave us the reliability we needed for this scale of deployment.Just wanted to share in case someone else is hitting a similar wallâ€”hope it saves you some time!hashtag#ESP32 hashtag#IoT hashtag#LittleFS hashtag#NVS hashtag#SPIFFS hashtag#FirmwareUpdate hashtag#EmbeddedSystems hashtag#MemoryManagement hashtag#TechFix

"ÙˆÙÙ‚ÙÙ„ Ø±ÙÙ‘Ø¨ÙÙ‘ Ø²ÙØ¯Ù’Ù†ÙÙŠ Ø¹ÙÙ„Ù’Ù…Ù‹Ø§" â€“ Ø³ÙˆØ±Ø© Ø·Ù‡ØŒ Ø§Ù„Ø¢ÙŠØ© 114ğŸ”§ MCSA Project 5: Deploying a Multi-Site Domain Controller with IFM and NIC Teaming â€“ A Real-World SimulationIâ€™ve just completed my fifth and most comprehensive MCSA project so far â€” a full-scale enterprise-level deployment involving multiple sites, advanced domain replication, and optimized server communication. Here's a breakdown of what I implemented:1ï¸âƒ£ Creating IFM Media for Domain Replication To simulate a real-world "Install From Media" (IFM) scenario, I generated a custom IFM package containing the Active Directory database and SYSVOL. Using ntdsutil via elevated CMD, I navigated to the IFM module and executed the command: create sysvol full C:\ifm This IFM folder allows a new domain controller to be promoted without replicating over the WAN â€” ideal for branch offices.2ï¸âƒ£ Lab Structure and Configuration I designed two sites: Cairo and Mansoura.Cairoâ€™s Server 2016 was configured as a Primary Domain Controller (PDC) and joined with a Windows 10 client in the same domain.The network was fully connected (pingable), and proper domain resolution was ensured through DNS configuration.I added a second Ethernet adapter and implemented NIC Teaming, enhancing bandwidth and redundancy.ğŸ’¡ NIC Teaming Benefits:Increased throughput via load balancingNetwork fault toleranceSeamless connectivity in case of NIC failure3ï¸âƒ£ Cloning and SID Regeneration for New Site To prepare the Mansoura site, I cloned the Cairo server and changed its SID using Sysprep to avoid domain conflicts. Upon reboot, the server was demoted to a Workgroup â€” a critical step in separating domain identity between sites.4ï¸âƒ£ Establishing Trust & Promoting the ADCI reconnected the Mansoura server to the Cairo network.Ensured two-way communication was functional (DNS + pingable).Installed Active Directory Domain Services on Mansoura's server.Promoted it as an Additional Domain Controller (ADC) using credentials from the existing domain (tshoot\administrator).Selected Mansoura as the site and enabled both DNS and Global Catalog roles.5ï¸âƒ£ IFM-Based User Replication Post-promotion, I imported the users from the previously created IFM folder. âœ… Users created in Cairo were instantly visible in Mansoura â€” proving successful replication.6ï¸âƒ£ Final TouchesRenamed servers accordingly: PDC (Cairo) and ADC (Mansoura)Disabled firewalls to avoid blocking replication or communicationInstalled VMware Tools to enhance performance and integrationğŸ’¼ This project was a deep dive into multi-site domain architecture, replication, network optimization, and disaster recovery readiness â€” and honestly, it felt like managing an enterprise-level infrastructure.Always striving to learn by doing, and this one was a milestone.Mohamed Tarek Zyad Waleed Elzyat Ali Khaled hashtag#MCSA hashtag#ActiveDirectory hashtag#Sysadmin hashtag#WindowsServer2016 hashtag#Networking hashtag#ITInfrastructure hashtag#NICTeaming hashtag#InstallFromMedia hashtag#LinkedInLearning hashtag#SysadminLife hashtag#MCSE hashtag#ITProjects

Day 18 : Understanding the difference between == and .equals() in Java is crucial for comparing objects correctly. Here's a fun and interactive way to grasp these concepts.ğŸ§  Understanding == vs .equals() in JavağŸ” The == OperatorWhat it does: Checks if two references point to the exact same object in memory.Use case: Best for comparing primitive data types (like int, char) or checking if two object references are identical.Medium+2Medium+2Scaler+2ğŸ§ª The .equals() MethodWhat it does: Compares the actual content or state of two objects.Use case: Ideal for comparing the contents of objects, such as strings, to see if they are logically "equal."ğŸ–¼ï¸ Visual RepresentationImagine two identical books:Scenario 1: Both friends are reading the same physical book. This is like using ==; both references point to the same object.Scenario 2: Each friend has their own copy of the book with the same  content. This is like using .equals(); different objects, but               identical content.ğŸ® Interactive Coding ChallengeLet's play a game with Java strings!javaCopyEditpublic class StringComparison { public static void main(String[] args) { String magicWord1 = "Abracadabra"; String magicWord2 = "Abracadabra"; String magicWord3 = new String("Abracadabra"); System.out.println(magicWord1 == magicWord2); // What will this print? System.out.println(magicWord1 == magicWord3); // And this? System.out.println(magicWord1.equals(magicWord3)); // How about this? }}ğŸ“Œ Follow along and challenge yourself daily!ğŸ’¡ I'll be sharing one Java trick daily! Back in 2020/21, remote work was hailed as the future. We saw bold predictions. More flexibility, reduced office space, asynchronous work, even the idea of holding multiple jobs remotely.Now in 2025, reality looks different.  Some gains held: hybrid work is more common, digital collaboration tools have matured, and employees expect flexibility. But letâ€™s be honest, many organizations have quietly reverted. Office mandates are back. The 8â€“5 structure remains dominant, and leadership? In many cases, still measuring productivity by attendance, not outcomes.What does this tell us?  Change happened, but not transformation. We adapted under pressure, but didnâ€™t redesign systems for the long term.If we are serious about the future of work, we need to stop treating flexibility as a perk and start embedding it into culture, policy, and performance management.2020 showed us whatâ€™s possible. 2025 is showing us whoâ€™s actually committed.hashtag#FutureOfWork hashtag#Leadership hashtag#WorkplaceCulture hashtag#RemoteWork hashtag#HRStrategy

When NVS Fails on ESP32â€¦ LittleFS to the Rescue! In one of our recent IoT projects, we ran into a tricky issue after rolling out a new firmware update (OTA) to all our ESP32-based devices. Out of nearly 30,000 units, about 100 started acting weirdâ€”some configs didnâ€™t load properly, and things just didnâ€™t add up.After digging into it, we found the root cause: we had increased the EEPROM size from 2KB to 5KB, and it turned out NVS couldnâ€™t handle it well on all devices.When we scanned the full memory, we saw corruption issues in those affected devices. ğŸ˜¬So, together with my teammates, we decided to shift our strategy.We moved our data and device configurations from NVS to SPIFFS using LittleFS ---> and it worked like a charm! ğŸ‹  Everything became stable and clean again.ğŸ” A quick takeaway:Sometimes NVS isn't the best fit for larger or dynamic data. LittleFS gave us the reliability we needed for this scale of deployment.Just wanted to share in case someone else is hitting a similar wallâ€”hope it saves you some time!hashtag#ESP32 hashtag#IoT hashtag#LittleFS hashtag#NVS hashtag#SPIFFS hashtag#FirmwareUpdate hashtag#EmbeddedSystems hashtag#MemoryManagement hashtag#TechFix

"ÙˆÙÙ‚ÙÙ„ Ø±ÙÙ‘Ø¨ÙÙ‘ Ø²ÙØ¯Ù’Ù†ÙÙŠ Ø¹ÙÙ„Ù’Ù…Ù‹Ø§" â€“ Ø³ÙˆØ±Ø© Ø·Ù‡ØŒ Ø§Ù„Ø¢ÙŠØ© 114ğŸ”§ MCSA Project 5: Deploying a Multi-Site Domain Controller with IFM and NIC Teaming â€“ A Real-World SimulationIâ€™ve just completed my fifth and most comprehensive MCSA project so far â€” a full-scale enterprise-level deployment involving multiple sites, advanced domain replication, and optimized server communication. Here's a breakdown of what I implemented:1ï¸âƒ£ Creating IFM Media for Domain Replication To simulate a real-world "Install From Media" (IFM) scenario, I generated a custom IFM package containing the Active Directory database and SYSVOL. Using ntdsutil via elevated CMD, I navigated to the IFM module and executed the command: create sysvol full C:\ifm This IFM folder allows a new domain controller to be promoted without replicating over the WAN â€” ideal for branch offices.2ï¸âƒ£ Lab Structure and Configuration I designed two sites: Cairo and Mansoura.Cairoâ€™s Server 2016 was configured as a Primary Domain Controller (PDC) and joined with a Windows 10 client in the same domain.The network was fully connected (pingable), and proper domain resolution was ensured through DNS configuration.I added a second Ethernet adapter and implemented NIC Teaming, enhancing bandwidth and redundancy.ğŸ’¡ NIC Teaming Benefits:Increased throughput via load balancingNetwork fault toleranceSeamless connectivity in case of NIC failure3ï¸âƒ£ Cloning and SID Regeneration for New Site To prepare the Mansoura site, I cloned the Cairo server and changed its SID using Sysprep to avoid domain conflicts. Upon reboot, the server was demoted to a Workgroup â€” a critical step in separating domain identity between sites.4ï¸âƒ£ Establishing Trust & Promoting the ADCI reconnected the Mansoura server to the Cairo network.Ensured two-way communication was functional (DNS + pingable).Installed Active Directory Domain Services on Mansoura's server.Promoted it as an Additional Domain Controller (ADC) using credentials from the existing domain (tshoot\administrator).Selected Mansoura as the site and enabled both DNS and Global Catalog roles.5ï¸âƒ£ IFM-Based User Replication Post-promotion, I imported the users from the previously created IFM folder. âœ… Users created in Cairo were instantly visible in Mansoura â€” proving successful replication.6ï¸âƒ£ Final TouchesRenamed servers accordingly: PDC (Cairo) and ADC (Mansoura)Disabled firewalls to avoid blocking replication or communicationInstalled VMware Tools to enhance performance and integrationğŸ’¼ This project was a deep dive into multi-site domain architecture, replication, network optimization, and disaster recovery readiness â€” and honestly, it felt like managing an enterprise-level infrastructure.Always striving to learn by doing, and this one was a milestone.Mohamed Tarek Zyad Waleed Elzyat Ali Khaled hashtag#MCSA hashtag#ActiveDirectory hashtag#Sysadmin hashtag#WindowsServer2016 hashtag#Networking hashtag#ITInfrastructure hashtag#NICTeaming hashtag#InstallFromMedia hashtag#LinkedInLearning hashtag#SysadminLife hashtag#MCSE hashtag#ITProjects

Day 18 : Understanding the difference between == and .equals() in Java is crucial for comparing objects correctly. Here's a fun and interactive way to grasp these concepts.ğŸ§  Understanding == vs .equals() in JavağŸ” The == OperatorWhat it does: Checks if two references point to the exact same object in memory.Use case: Best for comparing primitive data types (like int, char) or checking if two object references are identical.Medium+2Medium+2Scaler+2ğŸ§ª The .equals() MethodWhat it does: Compares the actual content or state of two objects.Use case: Ideal for comparing the contents of objects, such as strings, to see if they are logically "equal."ğŸ–¼ï¸ Visual RepresentationImagine two identical books:Scenario 1: Both friends are reading the same physical book. This is like using ==; both references point to the same object.Scenario 2: Each friend has their own copy of the book with the same  content. This is like using .equals(); different objects, but               identical content.ğŸ® Interactive Coding ChallengeLet's play a game with Java strings!javaCopyEditpublic class StringComparison { public static void main(String[] args) { String magicWord1 = "Abracadabra"; String magicWord2 = "Abracadabra"; String magicWord3 = new String("Abracadabra"); System.out.println(magicWord1 == magicWord2); // What will this print? System.out.println(magicWord1 == magicWord3); // And this? System.out.println(magicWord1.equals(magicWord3)); // How about this? }}ğŸ“Œ Follow along and challenge yourself daily!ğŸ’¡ I'll be sharing one Java trick daily! Back in 2020/21, remote work was hailed as the future. We saw bold predictions. More flexibility, reduced office space, asynchronous work, even the idea of holding multiple jobs remotely.Now in 2025, reality looks different.  Some gains held: hybrid work is more common, digital collaboration tools have matured, and employees expect flexibility. But letâ€™s be honest, many organizations have quietly reverted. Office mandates are back. The 8â€“5 structure remains dominant, and leadership? In many cases, still measuring productivity by attendance, not outcomes.What does this tell us?  Change happened, but not transformation. We adapted under pressure, but didnâ€™t redesign systems for the long term.If we are serious about the future of work, we need to stop treating flexibility as a perk and start embedding it into culture, policy, and performance management.2020 showed us whatâ€™s possible. 2025 is showing us whoâ€™s actually committed.hashtag#FutureOfWork hashtag#Leadership hashtag#WorkplaceCulture hashtag#RemoteWork hashtag#HRStrategy

When NVS Fails on ESP32â€¦ LittleFS to the Rescue! In one of our recent IoT projects, we ran into a tricky issue after rolling out a new firmware update (OTA) to all our ESP32-based devices. Out of nearly 30,000 units, about 100 started acting weirdâ€”some configs didnâ€™t load properly, and things just didnâ€™t add up.After digging into it, we found the root cause: we had increased the EEPROM size from 2KB to 5KB, and it turned out NVS couldnâ€™t handle it well on all devices.When we scanned the full memory, we saw corruption issues in those affected devices. ğŸ˜¬So, together with my teammates, we decided to shift our strategy.We moved our data and device configurations from NVS to SPIFFS using LittleFS ---> and it worked like a charm! ğŸ‹  Everything became stable and clean again.ğŸ” A quick takeaway:Sometimes NVS isn't the best fit for larger or dynamic data. LittleFS gave us the reliability we needed for this scale of deployment.Just wanted to share in case someone else is hitting a similar wallâ€”hope it saves you some time!hashtag#ESP32 hashtag#IoT hashtag#LittleFS hashtag#NVS hashtag#SPIFFS hashtag#FirmwareUpdate hashtag#EmbeddedSystems hashtag#MemoryManagement hashtag#TechFix

"ÙˆÙÙ‚ÙÙ„ Ø±ÙÙ‘Ø¨ÙÙ‘ Ø²ÙØ¯Ù’Ù†ÙÙŠ Ø¹ÙÙ„Ù’Ù…Ù‹Ø§" â€“ Ø³ÙˆØ±Ø© Ø·Ù‡ØŒ Ø§Ù„Ø¢ÙŠØ© 114ğŸ”§ MCSA Project 5: Deploying a Multi-Site Domain Controller with IFM and NIC Teaming â€“ A Real-World SimulationIâ€™ve just completed my fifth and most comprehensive MCSA project so far â€” a full-scale enterprise-level deployment involving multiple sites, advanced domain replication, and optimized server communication. Here's a breakdown of what I implemented:1ï¸âƒ£ Creating IFM Media for Domain Replication To simulate a real-world "Install From Media" (IFM) scenario, I generated a custom IFM package containing the Active Directory database and SYSVOL. Using ntdsutil via elevated CMD, I navigated to the IFM module and executed the command: create sysvol full C:\ifm This IFM folder allows a new domain controller to be promoted without replicating over the WAN â€” ideal for branch offices.2ï¸âƒ£ Lab Structure and Configuration I designed two sites: Cairo and Mansoura.Cairoâ€™s Server 2016 was configured as a Primary Domain Controller (PDC) and joined with a Windows 10 client in the same domain.The network was fully connected (pingable), and proper domain resolution was ensured through DNS configuration.I added a second Ethernet adapter and implemented NIC Teaming, enhancing bandwidth and redundancy.ğŸ’¡ NIC Teaming Benefits:Increased throughput via load balancingNetwork fault toleranceSeamless connectivity in case of NIC failure3ï¸âƒ£ Cloning and SID Regeneration for New Site To prepare the Mansoura site, I cloned the Cairo server and changed its SID using Sysprep to avoid domain conflicts. Upon reboot, the server was demoted to a Workgroup â€” a critical step in separating domain identity between sites.4ï¸âƒ£ Establishing Trust & Promoting the ADCI reconnected the Mansoura server to the Cairo network.Ensured two-way communication was functional (DNS + pingable).Installed Active Directory Domain Services on Mansoura's server.Promoted it as an Additional Domain Controller (ADC) using credentials from the existing domain (tshoot\administrator).Selected Mansoura as the site and enabled both DNS and Global Catalog roles.5ï¸âƒ£ IFM-Based User Replication Post-promotion, I imported the users from the previously created IFM folder. âœ… Users created in Cairo were instantly visible in Mansoura â€” proving successful replication.6ï¸âƒ£ Final TouchesRenamed servers accordingly: PDC (Cairo) and ADC (Mansoura)Disabled firewalls to avoid blocking replication or communicationInstalled VMware Tools to enhance performance and integrationğŸ’¼ This project was a deep dive into multi-site domain architecture, replication, network optimization, and disaster recovery readiness â€” and honestly, it felt like managing an enterprise-level infrastructure.Always striving to learn by doing, and this one was a milestone.Mohamed Tarek Zyad Waleed Elzyat Ali Khaled hashtag#MCSA hashtag#ActiveDirectory hashtag#Sysadmin hashtag#WindowsServer2016 hashtag#Networking hashtag#ITInfrastructure hashtag#NICTeaming hashtag#InstallFromMedia hashtag#LinkedInLearning hashtag#SysadminLife hashtag#MCSE hashtag#ITProjects

A quick thought on remote work and security...Lately, Iâ€™ve been seeing a lot of companies push return-to-office policies. The reason? "Security concerns."But hereâ€™s my take - remote work isnâ€™t insecure by default. What makes it insecure is the absence of structure.When teams are logging in from everywhere without a VPN, using personal devices, or sharing access looselyâ€”itâ€™s not the remote part thatâ€™s the problem. Itâ€™s the setup. The companies Iâ€™ve seen succeed with remote work donâ€™t treat it like a perk. They treat it like a system.A system with:â€“ Clear device policies â€“ Enforced MFA â€“ Role-based access â€“ Regular training (yes, even short, informal ones help)Set it up right, and it works. Efficiency stays high, risks stay low, and people get to do great work without sitting in traffic five days a week. Itâ€™s not about where we workâ€”itâ€™s about how we manage it.Curious if anyone else is seeing this shift. Are you going back to the officeâ€”or doubling down on getting remote right?hashtag#RemoteWork hashtag#CyberSecurity hashtag#Leadership hashtag#WorkplaceSecurity hashtag#InfoSec hashtag#WorkTrends

Day 18 : Understanding the difference between == and .equals() in Java is crucial for comparing objects correctly. Here's a fun and interactive way to grasp these concepts.ğŸ§  Understanding == vs .equals() in JavağŸ” The == OperatorWhat it does: Checks if two references point to the exact same object in memory.Use case: Best for comparing primitive data types (like int, char) or checking if two object references are identical.Medium+2Medium+2Scaler+2ğŸ§ª The .equals() MethodWhat it does: Compares the actual content or state of two objects.Use case: Ideal for comparing the contents of objects, such as strings, to see if they are logically "equal."ğŸ–¼ï¸ Visual RepresentationImagine two identical books:Scenario 1: Both friends are reading the same physical book. This is like using ==; both references point to the same object.Scenario 2: Each friend has their own copy of the book with the same  content. System.out.println(magicWord1 == magicWord3); // And this? System.out.println(magicWord1.equals(magicWord3)); // How about this? }}ğŸ“Œ Follow along and challenge yourself daily!ğŸ’¡ I'll be sharing one Java trick daily! Back in 2020/21, remote work was hailed as the future. We saw bold predictions. More flexibility, reduced office space, asynchronous work, even the idea of holding multiple jobs remotely.Now in 2025, reality looks different.  Some gains held: hybrid work is more common, digital collaboration tools have matured, and employees expect flexibility. But letâ€™s be honest, many organizations have quietly reverted. Office mandates are back. The 8â€“5 structure remains dominant, and leadership? In many cases, still measuring productivity by attendance, not outcomes.What does this tell us?  Change happened, but not transformation. We adapted under pressure, but didnâ€™t redesign systems for the long term.If we are serious about the future of work, we need to stop treating flexibility as a perk and start embedding it into culture, policy, and performance management.2020 showed us whatâ€™s possible. 2025 is showing us whoâ€™s actually committed.hashtag#FutureOfWork hashtag#Leadership hashtag#WorkplaceCulture hashtag#RemoteWork hashtag#HRStrategy

When NVS Fails on ESP32â€¦ LittleFS to the Rescue! In one of our recent IoT projects, we ran into a tricky issue after rolling out a new firmware update (OTA) to all our ESP32-based devices. Out of nearly 30,000 units, about 100 started acting weirdâ€”some configs didnâ€™t load properly, and things just didnâ€™t add up.After digging into it, we found the root cause: we had increased the EEPROM size from 2KB to 5KB, and it turned out NVS couldnâ€™t handle it well on all devices.When we scanned the full memory, we saw corruption issues in those affected devices. ğŸ˜¬So, together with my teammates, we decided to shift our strategy.We moved our data and device configurations from NVS to SPIFFS using LittleFS ---> and it worked like a charm! ğŸ‹  Everything became stable and clean again.ğŸ” A quick takeaway:Sometimes NVS isn't the best fit for larger or dynamic data. LittleFS gave us the reliability we needed for this scale of deployment.Just wanted to share in case someone else is hitting a similar wallâ€”hope it saves you some time!hashtag#ESP32 hashtag#IoT hashtag#LittleFS hashtag#NVS hashtag#SPIFFS hashtag#FirmwareUpdate hashtag#EmbeddedSystems hashtag#MemoryManagement hashtag#TechFix

"ÙˆÙÙ‚ÙÙ„ Ø±ÙÙ‘Ø¨ÙÙ‘ Ø²ÙØ¯Ù’Ù†ÙÙŠ Ø¹ÙÙ„Ù’Ù…Ù‹Ø§" â€“ Ø³ÙˆØ±Ø© Ø·Ù‡ØŒ Ø§Ù„Ø¢ÙŠØ© 114ğŸ”§ MCSA Project 5: Deploying a Multi-Site Domain Controller with IFM and NIC Teaming â€“ A Real-World SimulationIâ€™ve just completed my fifth and most comprehensive MCSA project so far â€” a full-scale enterprise-level deployment involving multiple sites, advanced domain replication, and optimized server communication. Here's a breakdown of what I implemented:1ï¸âƒ£ Creating IFM Media for Domain Replication To simulate a real-world "Install From Media" (IFM) scenario, I generated a custom IFM package containing the Active Directory database and SYSVOL. Using ntdsutil via elevated CMD, I navigated to the IFM module and executed the command: create sysvol full C:\ifm This IFM folder allows a new domain controller to be promoted without replicating over the WAN â€” ideal for branch offices.2ï¸âƒ£ Lab Structure and Configuration I designed two sites: Cairo and Mansoura.Cairoâ€™s Server 2016 was configured as a Primary Domain Controller (PDC) and joined with a Windows 10 client in the same domain.The network was fully connected (pingable), and proper domain resolution was ensured through DNS configuration.I added a second Ethernet adapter and implemented NIC Teaming, enhancing bandwidth and redundancy.ğŸ’¡ NIC Teaming Benefits:Increased throughput via load balancingNetwork fault toleranceSeamless connectivity in case of NIC failure3ï¸âƒ£ Cloning and SID Regeneration for New Site To prepare the Mansoura site, I cloned the Cairo server and changed its SID using Sysprep to avoid domain conflicts. Upon reboot, the server was demoted to a Workgroup â€” a critical step in separating domain identity between sites.4ï¸âƒ£ Establishing Trust & Promoting the ADCI reconnected the Mansoura server to the Cairo network.Ensured two-way communication was functional (DNS + pingable).Installed Active Directory Domain Services on Mansoura's server.Promoted it as an Additional Domain Controller (ADC) using credentials from the existing domain (tshoot\administrator).Selected Mansoura as the site and enabled both DNS and Global Catalog roles.5ï¸âƒ£ IFM-Based User Replication Post-promotion, I imported the users from the previously created IFM folder. âœ… Users created in Cairo were instantly visible in Mansoura â€” proving successful replication.6ï¸âƒ£ Final TouchesRenamed servers accordingly: PDC (Cairo) and ADC (Mansoura)Disabled firewalls to avoid blocking replication or communicationInstalled VMware Tools to enhance performance and integrationğŸ’¼ This project was a deep dive into multi-site domain architecture, replication, network optimization, and disaster recovery readiness â€” and honestly, it felt like managing an enterprise-level infrastructure.Always striving to learn by doing, and this one was a milestone.Mohamed Tarek Zyad Waleed Elzyat Ali Khaled hashtag#MCSA hashtag#ActiveDirectory hashtag#Sysadmin hashtag#WindowsServer2016 hashtag#Networking hashtag#ITInfrastructure hashtag#NICTeaming hashtag#InstallFromMedia hashtag#LinkedInLearning hashtag#SysadminLife hashtag#MCSE hashtag#ITProjects

A quick thought on remote work and security...Lately, Iâ€™ve been seeing a lot of companies push return-to-office policies. The reason? "Security concerns."But hereâ€™s my take - remote work isnâ€™t insecure by default. What makes it insecure is the absence of structure.When teams are logging in from everywhere without a VPN, using personal devices, or sharing access looselyâ€”itâ€™s not the remote part thatâ€™s the problem. Itâ€™s the setup. The companies Iâ€™ve seen succeed with remote work donâ€™t treat it like a perk. They treat it like a system.A system with:â€“ Clear device policies â€“ Enforced MFA â€“ Role-based access â€“ Regular training (yes, even short, informal ones help)Set it up right, and it works. Efficiency stays high, risks stay low, and people get to do great work without sitting in traffic five days a week. Itâ€™s not about where we workâ€”itâ€™s about how we manage it.Curious if anyone else is seeing this shift. Are you going back to the officeâ€”or doubling down on getting remote right?hashtag#RemoteWork hashtag#CyberSecurity hashtag#Leadership hashtag#WorkplaceSecurity hashtag#InfoSec hashtag#WorkTrends

ğŸ”§ Weekly Embedded Systems Challenge: "Smart Mailbox Notifier"ğŸ“¨ Main Challenge:Build a Smart Mailbox Notifier that detects when new mail is delivered and sends a notification (e.g., via LED, sound, or wireless message).ğŸ› ï¸ Core Requirements:Use a microcontroller (e.g., Arduino, ESP32, STM32, etc.).Include a sensor to detect the mailbox opening (magnetic reed switch, IR, ultrasonic, or light sensor).Use an output method to notify (LED, buzzer, or Wi-Fi/Bluetooth alert to phone).Ensure the system is battery-powered and low power, waking only on trigger.â­ Extra Credit (Advanced Tasks):Wireless Notification: Use Wi-Fi or Bluetooth to send a push notification or email when mail arrives.Battery Optimization: Implement deep sleep and power-saving strategies.Data Logging: Log timestamps of deliveries to local memory (SD card) or cloud.Tamper Detection: Add a secondary sensor to detect tampering or theft.Weatherproofing: Design a 3D-printed or rugged enclosure for outdoor deployment.ğŸ“¸ Share Your Work:Post a photo/video of your Smart Mailbox in action.Share your schematic, code, and power optimization tricks.Bonus: Create a GitHub repo or Instructable to document your build!ğŸ’¬ Community Discussion Starters:What other household objects could benefit from embedded automation?What are your favorite low-power microcontrollers or sleep strategies?How would you expand this into a smart home ecosystem?

Day 18 : Understanding the difference between == and .equals() in Java is crucial for comparing objects correctly. Here's a fun and interactive way to grasp these concepts.ğŸ§  Understanding == vs .equals() in JavağŸ” The == OperatorWhat it does: Checks if two references point to the exact same object in memory.Use case: Best for comparing primitive data types (like int, char) or checking if two object references are identical.Medium+2Medium+2Scaler+2ğŸ§ª The .equals() MethodWhat it does: Compares the actual content or state of two objects.Use case: Ideal for comparing the contents of objects, such as strings, to see if they are logically "equal."ğŸ–¼ï¸ Visual RepresentationImagine two identical books:Scenario 1: Both friends are reading the same physical book. This is like using ==; both references point to the same object.Scenario 2: Each friend has their own copy of the book with the same  content. This is like using .equals(); different objects, but               identical content.ğŸ® Interactive Coding ChallengeLet's play a game with Java strings!javaCopyEditpublic class StringComparison { public static void main(String[] args) { String magicWord1 = "Abracadabra"; String magicWord2 = "Abracadabra"; String magicWord3 = new String("Abracadabra"); System.out.println(magicWord1 == magicWord2); // What will this print? System.out.println(magicWord1 == magicWord3); // And this? System.out.println(magicWord1.equals(magicWord3)); // How about this? }}ğŸ“Œ Follow along and challenge yourself daily!ğŸ’¡ I'll be sharing one Java trick daily! Back in 2020/21, remote work was hailed as the future. We saw bold predictions. More flexibility, reduced office space, asynchronous work, even the idea of holding multiple jobs remotely.Now in 2025, reality looks different.  Some gains held: hybrid work is more common, digital collaboration tools have matured, and employees expect flexibility. But letâ€™s be honest, many organizations have quietly reverted. Office mandates are back. The 8â€“5 structure remains dominant, and leadership? In many cases, still measuring productivity by attendance, not outcomes.What does this tell us?  Change happened, but not transformation. We adapted under pressure, but didnâ€™t redesign systems for the long term.If we are serious about the future of work, we need to stop treating flexibility as a perk and start embedding it into culture, policy, and performance management.2020 showed us whatâ€™s possible. 2025 is showing us whoâ€™s actually committed.hashtag#FutureOfWork hashtag#Leadership hashtag#WorkplaceCulture hashtag#RemoteWork hashtag#HRStrategy

When NVS Fails on ESP32â€¦ LittleFS to the Rescue! In one of our recent IoT projects, we ran into a tricky issue after rolling out a new firmware update (OTA) to all our ESP32-based devices. Out of nearly 30,000 units, about 100 started acting weirdâ€”some configs didnâ€™t load properly, and things just didnâ€™t add up.After digging into it, we found the root cause: we had increased the EEPROM size from 2KB to 5KB, and it turned out NVS couldnâ€™t handle it well on all devices.When we scanned the full memory, we saw corruption issues in those affected devices. ğŸ˜¬So, together with my teammates, we decided to shift our strategy.We moved our data and device configurations from NVS to SPIFFS using LittleFS ---> and it worked like a charm! ğŸ‹  Everything became stable and clean again.ğŸ” A quick takeaway:Sometimes NVS isn't the best fit for larger or dynamic data. LittleFS gave us the reliability we needed for this scale of deployment.Just wanted to share in case someone else is hitting a similar wallâ€”hope it saves you some time!hashtag#ESP32 hashtag#IoT hashtag#LittleFS hashtag#NVS hashtag#SPIFFS hashtag#FirmwareUpdate hashtag#EmbeddedSystems hashtag#MemoryManagement hashtag#TechFix

"ÙˆÙÙ‚ÙÙ„ Ø±ÙÙ‘Ø¨ÙÙ‘ Ø²ÙØ¯Ù’Ù†ÙÙŠ Ø¹ÙÙ„Ù’Ù…Ù‹Ø§" â€“ Ø³ÙˆØ±Ø© Ø·Ù‡ØŒ Ø§Ù„Ø¢ÙŠØ© 114ğŸ”§ MCSA Project 5: Deploying a Multi-Site Domain Controller with IFM and NIC Teaming â€“ A Real-World SimulationIâ€™ve just completed my fifth and most comprehensive MCSA project so far â€” a full-scale enterprise-level deployment involving multiple sites, advanced domain replication, and optimized server communication. Here's a breakdown of what I implemented:1ï¸âƒ£ Creating IFM Media for Domain Replication To simulate a real-world "Install From Media" (IFM) scenario, I generated a custom IFM package containing the Active Directory database and SYSVOL. Using ntdsutil via elevated CMD, I navigated to the IFM module and executed the command: create sysvol full C:\ifm This IFM folder allows a new domain controller to be promoted without replicating over the WAN â€” ideal for branch offices.2ï¸âƒ£ Lab Structure and Configuration I designed two sites: Cairo and Mansoura.Cairoâ€™s Server 2016 was configured as a Primary Domain Controller (PDC) and joined with a Windows 10 client in the same domain.The network was fully connected (pingable), and proper domain resolution was ensured through DNS configuration.I added a second Ethernet adapter and implemented NIC Teaming, enhancing bandwidth and redundancy.ğŸ’¡ NIC Teaming Benefits:Increased throughput via load balancingNetwork fault toleranceSeamless connectivity in case of NIC failure3ï¸âƒ£ Cloning and SID Regeneration for New Site To prepare the Mansoura site, I cloned the Cairo server and changed its SID using Sysprep to avoid domain conflicts. Upon reboot, the server was demoted to a Workgroup â€” a critical step in separating domain identity between sites.4ï¸âƒ£ Establishing Trust & Promoting the ADCI reconnected the Mansoura server to the Cairo network.Ensured two-way communication was functional (DNS + pingable).Installed Active Directory Domain Services on Mansoura's server.Promoted it as an Additional Domain Controller (ADC) using credentials from the existing domain (tshoot\administrator).Selected Mansoura as the site and enabled both DNS and Global Catalog roles.5ï¸âƒ£ IFM-Based User Replication Post-promotion, I imported the users from the previously created IFM folder. âœ… Users created in Cairo were instantly visible in Mansoura â€” proving successful replication.6ï¸âƒ£ Final TouchesRenamed servers accordingly: PDC (Cairo) and ADC (Mansoura)Disabled firewalls to avoid blocking replication or communicationInstalled VMware Tools to enhance performance and integrationğŸ’¼ This project was a deep dive into multi-site domain architecture, replication, network optimization, and disaster recovery readiness â€” and honestly, it felt like managing an enterprise-level infrastructure.Always striving to learn by doing, and this one was a milestone.Mohamed Tarek Zyad Waleed Elzyat Ali Khaled hashtag#MCSA hashtag#ActiveDirectory hashtag#Sysadmin hashtag#WindowsServer2016 hashtag#Networking hashtag#ITInfrastructure hashtag#NICTeaming hashtag#InstallFromMedia hashtag#LinkedInLearning hashtag#SysadminLife hashtag#MCSE hashtag#ITProjects

A quick thought on remote work and security...Lately, Iâ€™ve been seeing a lot of companies push return-to-office policies. The reason? "Security concerns."But hereâ€™s my take - remote work isnâ€™t insecure by default. What makes it insecure is the absence of structure.When teams are logging in from everywhere without a VPN, using personal devices, or sharing access looselyâ€”itâ€™s not the remote part thatâ€™s the problem. Itâ€™s the setup. The companies Iâ€™ve seen succeed with remote work donâ€™t treat it like a perk. They treat it like a system.A system with:â€“ Clear device policies â€“ Enforced MFA â€“ Role-based access â€“ Regular training (yes, even short, informal ones help)Set it up right, and it works. Efficiency stays high, risks stay low, and people get to do great work without sitting in traffic five days a week. Itâ€™s not about where we workâ€”itâ€™s about how we manage it.Curious if anyone else is seeing this shift. Are you going back to the officeâ€”or doubling down on getting remote right?hashtag#RemoteWork hashtag#CyberSecurity hashtag#Leadership hashtag#WorkplaceSecurity hashtag#InfoSec hashtag#WorkTrends

ğŸ”§ Weekly Embedded Systems Challenge: "Smart Mailbox Notifier"ğŸ“¨ Main Challenge:Build a Smart Mailbox Notifier that detects when new mail is delivered and sends a notification (e.g., via LED, sound, or wireless message).ğŸ› ï¸ Core Requirements:Use a microcontroller (e.g., Arduino, ESP32, STM32, etc.).Include a sensor to detect the mailbox opening (magnetic reed switch, IR, ultrasonic, or light sensor).Use an output method to notify (LED, buzzer, or Wi-Fi/Bluetooth alert to phone).Ensure the system is battery-powered and low power, waking only on trigger.â­ Extra Credit (Advanced Tasks):Wireless Notification: Use Wi-Fi or Bluetooth to send a push notification or email when mail arrives.Battery Optimization: Implement deep sleep and power-saving strategies.Data Logging: Log timestamps of deliveries to local memory (SD card) or cloud.Tamper Detection: Add a secondary sensor to detect tampering or theft.Weatherproofing: Design a 3D-printed or rugged enclosure for outdoor deployment.ğŸ“¸ Share Your Work:Post a photo/video of your Smart Mailbox in action.Share your schematic, code, and power optimization tricks.Bonus: Create a GitHub repo or Instructable to document your build!ğŸ’¬ Community Discussion Starters:What other household objects could benefit from embedded automation?What are your favorite low-power microcontrollers or sleep strategies?How would you expand this into a smart home ecosystem?

Day 18 : Understanding the difference between == and .equals() in Java is crucial for comparing objects correctly. Here's a fun and interactive way to grasp these concepts.ğŸ§  Understanding == vs .equals() in JavağŸ” The == OperatorWhat it does: Checks if two references point to the exact same object in memory.Use case: Best for comparing primitive data types (like int, char) or checking if two object references are identical.Medium+2Medium+2Scaler+2ğŸ§ª The .equals() MethodWhat it does: Compares the actual content or state of two objects.Use case: Ideal for comparing the contents of objects, such as strings, to see if they are logically "equal."ğŸ–¼ï¸ Visual RepresentationImagine two identical books:Scenario 1: Both friends are reading the same physical book. This is like using ==; both references point to the same object.Scenario 2: Each friend has their own copy of the book with the same  content. This is like using .equals(); different objects, but               identical content.ğŸ® Interactive Coding ChallengeLet's play a game with Java strings!javaCopyEditpublic class StringComparison { public static void main(String[] args) { String magicWord1 = "Abracadabra"; String magicWord2 = "Abracadabra"; String magicWord3 = new String("Abracadabra"); System.out.println(magicWord1 == magicWord2); // What will this print? System.out.println(magicWord1 == magicWord3); // And this? System.out.println(magicWord1.equals(magicWord3)); // How about this? }}ğŸ“Œ Follow along and challenge yourself daily!ğŸ’¡ I'll be sharing one Java trick daily! Back in 2020/21, remote work was hailed as the future. We saw bold predictions. More flexibility, reduced office space, asynchronous work, even the idea of holding multiple jobs remotely.Now in 2025, reality looks different.  Some gains held: hybrid work is more common, digital collaboration tools have matured, and employees expect flexibility. But letâ€™s be honest, many organizations have quietly reverted. Office mandates are back. The 8â€“5 structure remains dominant, and leadership? In many cases, still measuring productivity by attendance, not outcomes.What does this tell us?  Change happened, but not transformation. We adapted under pressure, but didnâ€™t redesign systems for the long term.If we are serious about the future of work, we need to stop treating flexibility as a perk and start embedding it into culture, policy, and performance management.2020 showed us whatâ€™s possible. 2025 is showing us whoâ€™s actually committed.hashtag#FutureOfWork hashtag#Leadership hashtag#WorkplaceCulture hashtag#RemoteWork hashtag#HRStrategy

When NVS Fails on ESP32â€¦ LittleFS to the Rescue! In one of our recent IoT projects, we ran into a tricky issue after rolling out a new firmware update (OTA) to all our ESP32-based devices. Out of nearly 30,000 units, about 100 started acting weirdâ€”some configs didnâ€™t load properly, and things just didnâ€™t add up.After digging into it, we found the root cause: we had increased the EEPROM size from 2KB to 5KB, and it turned out NVS couldnâ€™t handle it well on all devices.When we scanned the full memory, we saw corruption issues in those affected devices. ğŸ˜¬So, together with my teammates, we decided to shift our strategy.We moved our data and device configurations from NVS to SPIFFS using LittleFS ---> and it worked like a charm! ğŸ‹  Everything became stable and clean again.ğŸ” A quick takeaway:Sometimes NVS isn't the best fit for larger or dynamic data. LittleFS gave us the reliability we needed for this scale of deployment.Just wanted to share in case someone else is hitting a similar wallâ€”hope it saves you some time!hashtag#ESP32 hashtag#IoT hashtag#LittleFS hashtag#NVS hashtag#SPIFFS hashtag#FirmwareUpdate hashtag#EmbeddedSystems hashtag#MemoryManagement hashtag#TechFix

"ÙˆÙÙ‚ÙÙ„ Ø±ÙÙ‘Ø¨ÙÙ‘ Ø²ÙØ¯Ù’Ù†ÙÙŠ Ø¹ÙÙ„Ù’Ù…Ù‹Ø§" â€“ Ø³ÙˆØ±Ø© Ø·Ù‡ØŒ Ø§Ù„Ø¢ÙŠØ© 114ğŸ”§ MCSA Project 5: Deploying a Multi-Site Domain Controller with IFM and NIC Teaming â€“ A Real-World SimulationIâ€™ve just completed my fifth and most comprehensive MCSA project so far â€” a full-scale enterprise-level deployment involving multiple sites, advanced domain replication, and optimized server communication. Here's a breakdown of what I implemented:1ï¸âƒ£ Creating IFM Media for Domain Replication To simulate a real-world "Install From Media" (IFM) scenario, I generated a custom IFM package containing the Active Directory database and SYSVOL. Using ntdsutil via elevated CMD, I navigated to the IFM module and executed the command: create sysvol full C:\ifm This IFM folder allows a new domain controller to be promoted without replicating over the WAN â€” ideal for branch offices.2ï¸âƒ£ Lab Structure and Configuration I designed two sites: Cairo and Mansoura.Cairoâ€™s Server 2016 was configured as a Primary Domain Controller (PDC) and joined with a Windows 10 client in the same domain.The network was fully connected (pingable), and proper domain resolution was ensured through DNS configuration.I added a second Ethernet adapter and implemented NIC Teaming, enhancing bandwidth and redundancy.ğŸ’¡ NIC Teaming Benefits:Increased throughput via load balancingNetwork fault toleranceSeamless connectivity in case of NIC failure3ï¸âƒ£ Cloning and SID Regeneration for New Site To prepare the Mansoura site, I cloned the Cairo server and changed its SID using Sysprep to avoid domain conflicts. Upon reboot, the server was demoted to a Workgroup â€” a critical step in separating domain identity between sites.4ï¸âƒ£ Establishing Trust & Promoting the ADCI reconnected the Mansoura server to the Cairo network.Ensured two-way communication was functional (DNS + pingable).Installed Active Directory Domain Services on Mansoura's server.Promoted it as an Additional Domain Controller (ADC) using credentials from the existing domain (tshoot\administrator).Selected Mansoura as the site and enabled both DNS and Global Catalog roles.5ï¸âƒ£ IFM-Based User Replication Post-promotion, I imported the users from the previously created IFM folder. âœ… Users created in Cairo were instantly visible in Mansoura â€” proving successful replication.6ï¸âƒ£ Final TouchesRenamed servers accordingly: PDC (Cairo) and ADC (Mansoura)Disabled firewalls to avoid blocking replication or communicationInstalled VMware Tools to enhance performance and integrationğŸ’¼ This project was a deep dive into multi-site domain architecture, replication, network optimization, and disaster recovery readiness â€” and honestly, it felt like managing an enterprise-level infrastructure.Always striving to learn by doing, and this one was a milestone.Mohamed Tarek Zyad Waleed Elzyat Ali Khaled hashtag#MCSA hashtag#ActiveDirectory hashtag#Sysadmin hashtag#WindowsServer2016 hashtag#Networking hashtag#ITInfrastructure hashtag#NICTeaming hashtag#InstallFromMedia hashtag#LinkedInLearning hashtag#SysadminLife hashtag#MCSE hashtag#ITProjects

A quick thought on remote work and security...Lately, Iâ€™ve been seeing a lot of companies push return-to-office policies. The reason? "Security concerns."But hereâ€™s my take - remote work isnâ€™t insecure by default. What makes it insecure is the absence of structure.When teams are logging in from everywhere without a VPN, using personal devices, or sharing access looselyâ€”itâ€™s not the remote part thatâ€™s the problem. Itâ€™s the setup. The companies Iâ€™ve seen succeed with remote work donâ€™t treat it like a perk. They treat it like a system.A system with:â€“ Clear device policies â€“ Enforced MFA â€“ Role-based access â€“ Regular training (yes, even short, informal ones help)Set it up right, and it works. Efficiency stays high, risks stay low, and people get to do great work without sitting in traffic five days a week. Itâ€™s not about where we workâ€”itâ€™s about how we manage it.Curious if anyone else is seeing this shift. Are you going back to the officeâ€”or doubling down on getting remote right?hashtag#RemoteWork hashtag#CyberSecurity hashtag#Leadership hashtag#WorkplaceSecurity hashtag#InfoSec hashtag#WorkTrends

ğŸ”§ Weekly Embedded Systems Challenge: "Smart Mailbox Notifier"ğŸ“¨ Main Challenge:Build a Smart Mailbox Notifier that detects when new mail is delivered and sends a notification (e.g., via LED, sound, or wireless message).ğŸ› ï¸ Core Requirements:Use a microcontroller (e.g., Arduino, ESP32, STM32, etc.).Include a sensor to detect the mailbox opening (magnetic reed switch, IR, ultrasonic, or light sensor).Use an output method to notify (LED, buzzer, or Wi-Fi/Bluetooth alert to phone).Ensure the system is battery-powered and low power, waking only on trigger.â­ Extra Credit (Advanced Tasks):Wireless Notification: Use Wi-Fi or Bluetooth to send a push notification or email when mail arrives.Battery Optimization: Implement deep sleep and power-saving strategies.Data Logging: Log timestamps of deliveries to local memory (SD card) or cloud.Tamper Detection: Add a secondary sensor to detect tampering or theft.Weatherproofing: Design a 3D-printed or rugged enclosure for outdoor deployment.ğŸ“¸ Share Your Work:Post a photo/video of your Smart Mailbox in action.Share your schematic, code, and power optimization tricks.Bonus: Create a GitHub repo or Instructable to document your build!ğŸ’¬ Community Discussion Starters:What other household objects could benefit from embedded automation?What are your favorite low-power microcontrollers or sleep strategies?How would you expand this into a smart home ecosystem?

Here's a fun and interactive way to grasp these concepts.ğŸ§  Understanding == vs .equals() in JavağŸ” The == OperatorWhat it does: Checks if two references point to the exact same object in memory.Use case: Best for comparing primitive data types (like int, char) or checking if two object references are identical.Medium+2Medium+2Scaler+2ğŸ§ª The .equals() MethodWhat it does: Compares the actual content or state of two objects.Use case: Ideal for comparing the contents of objects, such as strings, to see if they are logically "equal."ğŸ–¼ï¸ Visual RepresentationImagine two identical books:Scenario 1: Both friends are reading the same physical book. This is like using ==; both references point to the same object.Scenario 2: Each friend has their own copy of the book with the same  content. This is like using .equals(); different objects, but               identical content.ğŸ® Interactive Coding ChallengeLet's play a game with Java strings!javaCopyEditpublic class StringComparison { public static void main(String[] args) { String magicWord1 = "Abracadabra"; String magicWord2 = "Abracadabra"; String magicWord3 = new String("Abracadabra"); System.out.println(magicWord1 == magicWord2); // What will this print? System.out.println(magicWord1 == magicWord3); // And this? System.out.println(magicWord1.equals(magicWord3)); // How about this? }}ğŸ“Œ Follow along and challenge yourself daily!ğŸ’¡ I'll be sharing one Java trick daily! Back in 2020/21, remote work was hailed as the future. We saw bold predictions. More flexibility, reduced office space, asynchronous work, even the idea of holding multiple jobs remotely.Now in 2025, reality looks different.  Some gains held: hybrid work is more common, digital collaboration tools have matured, and employees expect flexibility. But letâ€™s be honest, many organizations have quietly reverted. Office mandates are back. The 8â€“5 structure remains dominant, and leadership? In many cases, still measuring productivity by attendance, not outcomes.What does this tell us?  Change happened, but not transformation. We adapted under pressure, but didnâ€™t redesign systems for the long term.If we are serious about the future of work, we need to stop treating flexibility as a perk and start embedding it into culture, policy, and performance management.2020 showed us whatâ€™s possible. 2025 is showing us whoâ€™s actually committed.hashtag#FutureOfWork hashtag#Leadership hashtag#WorkplaceCulture hashtag#RemoteWork hashtag#HRStrategy

When NVS Fails on ESP32â€¦ LittleFS to the Rescue! In one of our recent IoT projects, we ran into a tricky issue after rolling out a new firmware update (OTA) to all our ESP32-based devices. Out of nearly 30,000 units, about 100 started acting weirdâ€”some configs didnâ€™t load properly, and things just didnâ€™t add up.After digging into it, we found the root cause: we had increased the EEPROM size from 2KB to 5KB, and it turned out NVS couldnâ€™t handle it well on all devices.When we scanned the full memory, we saw corruption issues in those affected devices. ğŸ˜¬So, together with my teammates, we decided to shift our strategy.We moved our data and device configurations from NVS to SPIFFS using LittleFS ---> and it worked like a charm! ğŸ‹  Everything became stable and clean again.ğŸ” A quick takeaway:Sometimes NVS isn't the best fit for larger or dynamic data. LittleFS gave us the reliability we needed for this scale of deployment.Just wanted to share in case someone else is hitting a similar wallâ€”hope it saves you some time!hashtag#ESP32 hashtag#IoT hashtag#LittleFS hashtag#NVS hashtag#SPIFFS hashtag#FirmwareUpdate hashtag#EmbeddedSystems hashtag#MemoryManagement hashtag#TechFix
